title: 105_s1312
content:
The "Child Passenger Protection Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The Act includes findings related to child passenger safety. Congress finds that annual losses in the United States from motor vehicle collisions exceed 800 deaths and 80,000 injuries to children under 5. Properly used child restraints can reduce serious or fatal injuries by 69% for infants and 47% for children under 5. Common seating designs in vehicles make secure installation of child restraints difficult. Regional clinics show that 70-90% of child restraints are not installed correctly. There is a high rate of improper installation or misuse of child restraints, largely due to the complexity and variations in seat belt and child restraint designs. It is crucial to expand national, State, and local education programs to effectively educate the public on proper child restraint use. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Child restraint education program includes publication, audiovisual presentation, demonstration, or computerized program. Secretary refers to the Secretary of Transportation. State means any State of the United States, including territories and possessions.

SEC. 4. CHILD PASSENGER EDUCATION. The Secretary can provide funding to State highway agencies and child passenger safety organizations for child restraint education programs. The programs aim to prevent injuries to children under 5 and educate the public on proper installation of child restraints. The funding provided by the Secretary supports child restraint education programs, which involve training professionals on installation techniques, restraint design selection, and harness adjustment. Additionally, funds are allocated for nationwide education programs and support for child restraint use. The Secretary's funding supports child restraint education programs, with 25% for existing State programs and 50% for new national, State, and local programs. SEC. 5. APPLICATIONS AND REPORTS. To enter into a contract, cooperative agreement, or grant agreement under section 4(a), the appropriate official of an agency or organization must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The agency or organization must also prepare and submit an annual report to the Secretary, detailing program activities and any additional information requested. The agency or organization must submit an application to the Secretary with required information to enter into a contract, cooperative agreement, or grant agreement under section 4(a. They must also provide an annual report detailing program activities and any additional information requested. The report should describe the program activities undertaken with the funds, including child restraint education programs, support materials obtained, and initiatives for public development. The agency or organization is required to develop public-private partnerships for child restraint education programs and materials. The Secretary must report to Congress annually on the implementation of the Act, detailing programs and materials developed by funded agencies. $7,500,000 is authorized for the Department of Transportation for fiscal years 1998 and 1999, with a limit of $350,000 for administrative costs.
